availability.p: Material from the Romantic Circles Website may not be downloaded, reproduced or disseminated in any manner without authorization unless it is for purposes of criticism, comment, news reporting, teaching, and/or classroom use as provided by the Copyright Act of 1976, as amended.

Unless otherwise noted, all Pages and Resources mounted on Romantic Circles are copyrighted by the author/editor and may be shared only in accordance with the Fair Use provisions of U.S. copyright law. Except as expressly permitted by this statement, redistribution or republication in any medium requires express prior written consent from the author(s)/ editor(s) and advance notification of Romantic Circles. Any requests for authorization should be forwarded to Romantic Circles: Romantic Circles c/o Professor Thora Brylowe Department of English University of Colorado Boulder Boulder, CO 80309 thora.brylowe@colorado.edu

By their use of these texts and images, users agree to the following conditions:
These texts and images may not be used for any commercial purpose without prior written permission from Romantic Circles.
These texts and images may not be re-distributed in any forms other than their current ones.

Users are not permitted to download these texts and images in order to mount them on their own servers. It is not in our interest or that of our users to have uncontrolled subsets of our holdings available elsewhere on the Internet. We make corrections and additions to our edited resources on a continual basis, and we want the most current text to be the only one generally available to all Internet users. Institutions can, of course, make a link to the copies at Romantic Circles, subject to our conditions of use.

analytic.title: Table of Contents 1A: Starting from Front Cover

monogr.title: Dorothy Wordsworth’s Lake District: Poems from the Commonplace Book (1805–1835?)
Editions

imprint.publisher: Romantic Circles, https://romantic-circles.org, University of Colorado Boulder

quotation.p: All quotation marks and apostrophes have been changed: " to “ or ”, and ' to ‘ and ’.

hyphenation.p: Any dashes occurring in line breaks have been removed except in the case of diplomatic transcriptions.
Because of web browser variability, all hyphens have been typed on the U.S. keyboard
Em dashes have been rendered as —
En dashes have been rendered as –

normalization.p: Writing in other hands appearing on these manuscripts has been indicated as such, the content recorded in brackets.
& has been used for the ampersand sign.
# has been used for #, the pound sign
All other characters, those with accents, non-breaking spaces, etc., have been encoded in HTML entity decimals.

div.head: Table of Contents 1A: Starting from Front Cover

row.cell: Newspaper articles, one an illustration captioned “The Pitt Press” and the other “Life and travels of the Apostle Paul.”
26th June 1830—Sunday Evening—Dictated by William Wordsworth to Dorothy Wordsworth Penr.
“In this fair vale hath many a tree”
Dr. Schoeffer’s Prescriptions for and experience in the cure of the cholera—Mortons—Vienna.
Copy of Mr Carr’s statement for Dr. W. Philips, 28th July 1824.
By liking, a friendship may grow out of strife; / But love is the sunshine & starlight of life.
Copy of a poem written by William Wordsworth as a school exercise. He was then 14 years old.
“And has the sun his flaming chariot driven”
Copy of a letter to Hindley, 6 Grays Inn, October 4th, 1830, from William Wordsworth.
For a monument to be placed in the grounds of Coleorton Hall Leicestershire to the Memory of the late George Howland Beaumont.
“With copious eulogy in prose or rhyme”
Extracts from the commonplace book of Isabella Countess of Glencairn. Who died at Boulogne after a residence there of several years. … [First entry dated Jan 17th 1820]
From the mouth of the Countess of Glencairn—written down by Miss Barker (Ms Slade Smith) and copied from her Sarah Book
On the Birth of Mr. Middleton’s eldest child—a son. … Mary Barker Janry 6th 1816 Copied by D.W. Sr.
“Of all the ancient House first born”
26th June 1830. Dictated by W Wordsworth to D Wordsworth Senior. Recopied August 2nd 1832, D Wordsworth.
“In this fair Vale hath many a Tree”
Lines addressed to Joanna Hutchinson from Gwerndovennant June 1826 [Version A].
“Now, at the close of fervid June”
Irregular Stanzas / Holiday at Gwerndovennant May 1826 [Version A].
“‘You’re here for one long vernal day”
Holiday at Gwerndovennant / Irregular Stanzas [Version B].
“You’re here for one long vernal day”
Insert 1bLarge cream sheet (23 cm x 37 cm) with wax seals; poem written in two columns. Includes signature “Miss Dora Wordsworth. No room for Mrs Henderson’s Letter”
Insert 2aLilac, chain-lined paper, measuring 20 cm x 32 cm and stamped “Stamp Office Carlisle Inland Revenue”; poem in two columns and written in two directions on verso.
Insert 2b The two “2bs” reflect that this page is bisected, as it is bound to the notebook folded.
“Here too in many a sheltered chink”
“The worship of this Sabbath morn (four stanzas only)”
“There is one cottage in our Dale”
A cottage in Grasmere Vale [Version B of Grasmere—A Fragment].
“Yet when I sit on rock or hill”
After-recollections at the sight of the same Cottage [Version C of Grasmere—A Fragment].
“When first I saw that dear abode”
A winter’s ramble in Grasmere Vale [Version D of Grasmere—A Fragment].
“Beneath that rock my course I stayed”
To Julia Marshall – A Fragment [Version A].
Memorandum of an adventure in Dr. Andrew Bell’s early life taken from the mouth of his sister at Cheltenham May 30th 1831.
